0-6months.developmentalStage: Newborn/Infant - Sensory exploration and bonding phase
cognitiveAbilities: Processing sensory stimuli (light, sound, touch, smell)
Exploring cause and effect (e.g., shaking rattle makes noise)
languageMilestones: Turns and reacts to familiar sounds
0-6months.attentionSpan: Very brief - seconds to 1-2 minutes maximum

musicalPreferences.instruments: Soft acoustic, gentle percussion, music box sounds
musicalPreferences.characteristics: Simple melodies, repetitive patterns, soothing timbres

0-6months.motorSkills: Limited - rolls over, brings things to mouth, develops basic coordination

lyricGuidelines.vocabulary: Simple, repetitive words (mama, baby, sleep, love)
lyricGuidelines.perspective: Second person (talking to baby) or third person (about baby)
lyricGuidelines.exampleStructure: Verse repeats with minimal variation, no chorus needed

scientificNotes: Fetuses respond to music from 28 weeks gestation
Newborns are more attentive to infant-directed singing
Lullabies decrease heart rate and induce relaxation
Infants respond to universal lullaby elements across cultures
Music mimicking mother's heartbeat is most calming

6-12months.developmentalStage: Baby - Active exploration and early communication
cognitiveAbilities: Puts objects in containers and removes them
languageMilestones: Recognizes songs and sounds, reacts to them
6-12months.vocabularyLevel: First words emerging (1-10 words by 12 months)

musicalPreferences.tempo: 60-100 BPM (slower for calm, moderate for play)
musicalPreferences.style: Lullabies, simple play songs, peek-a-boo songs
musicalPreferences.characteristics: Call and response patterns, simple melodies, exaggerated dynamics

6-12months.motorSkills: Sits without support, crawls, stands with support, develops pincer grasp

lyricGuidelines.vocabulary: Common first words (mama, dada, baby, dog, cat, ball)
lyricGuidelines.repetition: Very high - verses repeat with predictable changes
lyricGuidelines.perspective: Second person or first person plural (we/us)
lyricGuidelines.exampleStructure: Verse-Verse-Verse with actions, optional simple chorus

scientificNotes: Babies prefer faster tempos for play songs vs. lullabies
Context-dependent musical preferences emerge
Music supports early word learning and memory
Rhythmic movement enhances neural development
Songs with gestures support language acquisition

1-2years.developmentalStage: Young Toddler - Language explosion and independence seeking
cognitiveAbilities: Points to body parts when named
languageMilestones: Vocabulary expands rapidly: 10-50 words by age 2
Begins combining two words into phrases

musicalPreferences.style: Action songs, simple narratives, animal songs, repetitive tunes
musicalPreferences.vocals: Clear, animated singing with character voices
musicalPreferences.instruments: Drums, xylophones, tambourines, simple rhythm instruments
musicalPreferences.characteristics: Predictable patterns, opportunities for participation, movement-based

1-2years.socialDevelopment: Parallel play, awareness of others, beginning to share (with prompting)
1-2years.motorSkills: Walks alone, climbs steps, kicks and throws balls, stands on tiptoes
affirmationExamples: I am loved just the way I am

lyricGuidelines.vocabulary: Common nouns, action verbs, simple adjectives
lyricGuidelines.repetition: High - chorus repeats 3-4 times, verses have familiar structure
lyricGuidelines.perspective: First person ('I can jump'), second person ('You are happy'), imperative ('Clap your hands')

scientificNotes: Music vocabulary building is most effective at this age
Songs double word retention compared to stories
Repetitive music supports language pattern recognition
Movement songs enhance brain-body connection
Music supports emotional regulation during tantrums

2-3years.developmentalStage: Toddler - Imaginative play and social awareness
cognitiveAbilities: Attention span increases to ~3 minutes for structured activities
Turns pages, pushes buttons, turns knobs
languageMilestones: Introduces self with name, age, gender

musicalPreferences.tempo: 90-130 BPM (varied - can handle more dynamic range)
musicalPreferences.style: Story songs, counting songs, alphabet introduction, character songs
musicalPreferences.vocals: Clear articulation, character differentiation, emotional expression
musicalPreferences.instruments: Wider variety - piano, guitar, drums, bells, whistles
musicalPreferences.characteristics: Simple narratives, call-and-response, predictable verses with surprises

2-3years.socialDevelopment: Parallel play transitions to associative play, taking turns (with support), copying others
2-3years.motorSkills: Walks stairs one foot per step, runs easily, pedals tricycle, uses scissors
affirmationExamples: I can share with my friends
I can calm down when I'm upset

lyricGuidelines.vocabulary: Expanded nouns, descriptive adjectives, helping verbs
lyricGuidelines.repetition: Moderate-high - chorus repeats, verses add new information
lyricGuidelines.perspective: First person ('I can share'), second person ('You're my friend'), narrative ('The bear went up the mountain')

scientificNotes: Phonological awareness develops rapidly
Rhyming songs are best predictors of literacy success
Music enhances pattern recognition for math
Social-emotional songs support cooperation
Repetitive music builds executive function

3-4years.developmentalStage: Preschooler - Cooperative play and conceptual learning
cognitiveAbilities: Can recite poems and songs from memory
languageMilestones: Tells stories with beginning, middle, end

musicalPreferences.style: Story-based songs, learning songs, silly songs, group participation songs
musicalPreferences.vocals: Expressive, clear, character voices, harmonies introduction
musicalPreferences.instruments: Full range - orchestral sounds, band instruments, world instruments
musicalPreferences.characteristics: Narrative arcs, humor, surprise elements, cumulative songs

3-4years.socialDevelopment: Cooperative play, forming friendships, understanding rules, empathy emerging
3-4years.motorSkills: Hops on one foot, stands on one foot briefly, catches ball, cuts with scissors accurately
affirmationExamples: I am a good problem solver
I am brave when trying new things
I can ask for help when I need it
I am proud of what I can do
songTopics: Full alphabet and letter sounds (phonics intro)

lyricGuidelines.repetition: Moderate - chorus repeats, verses tell progressive story
lyricGuidelines.rhymeScheme: Varied - AABB, ABCB, ABAB, even ABCD with internal rhymes

scientificNotes: Executive functions (attention, inhibitory control) strengthen with music
Music enhances spatial-temporal reasoning
Group singing builds social cohesion
Phonemic awareness critical for reading readiness
Music activates multiple brain regions simultaneously

musicalPreferences.style: Educational pop, story ballads, comedy songs, call-and-response, echo songs
musicalPreferences.instruments: Rock band setup, orchestral, electronic sounds, world music
musicalPreferences.characteristics: Catchy hooks, humor, educational content, participation opportunities

learningModalities: Phonics and early reading through song
4-5years.socialDevelopment: Complex cooperative play, best friends, rule-following, leadership roles
4-5years.motorSkills: Stands on one foot 10 seconds, somersaults, skips smoothly, writes letters
affirmationExamples: I am ready to learn new things
songTopics: Science (solar system, animals, plants, human body)

lyricGuidelines.vocabulary: Academic vocabulary, precise descriptors, compound words
lyricGuidelines.rhymeScheme: Sophisticated patterns, internal rhymes, slant rhymes
lyricGuidelines.exampleStructure: Full song structure with intro, multiple verses, pre-chorus, chorus, bridge, outro

scientificNotes: Music training enhances reading skills
Rhythm supports mathematical thinking
Music improves auditory processing for language
Group music enhances social cognition
Musical memory supports academic memory

5-6years.developmentalStage: Kindergarten - Formal learning and social complexity
cognitiveAbilities: Attention span 10-20 minutes for structured learning
5-6years.attentionSpan: 10-20 minutes, longer for highly engaging content

musicalPreferences.style: All genres - pop, rock, hip-hop, folk, classical, world music
musicalPreferences.instruments: Full spectrum of sounds and instruments
musicalPreferences.characteristics: Sophisticated lyrics, educational depth, humor, relatability

learningModalities: Reading and literacy through song lyrics
5-6years.socialDevelopment: Complex friendships, team activities, conflict resolution, leadership and followership
5-6years.motorSkills: Refined motor control, can play instruments with technique, coordinated dance
affirmationExamples: I can overcome challenges with practice
My mistakes are opportunities to grow
I am responsible for my actions
I can work well with others
I am prepared for new adventures

lyricGuidelines.vocabulary: Grade-level academic vocabulary, figurative language introduction
lyricGuidelines.repetition: Strategic - catchy elements repeated, verses provide depth
lyricGuidelines.perspective: Multiple perspectives within one song possible
lyricGuidelines.exampleStructure: Professional song structure with multiple sections, possible rap verse or spoken word

scientificNotes: 85% of brain developed by age 5
Music enhances all academic domains
Long-term music training shows structural brain changes
Music supports executive function development
Social music-making builds empathy and cooperation

repetitionStrategy.0-2years: Very high repetition (80-90% of song is repeated elements)
repetitionStrategy.4-6years: Strategic repetition (chorus and hook, verses tell story)

vocabularyProgression.principle: Use vocabulary at child's current level + 10-20% stretch words
vocabularyProgression.contextClues: Always provide context for new words through repetition and description
vocabularyProgression.pronunciation: Clear, exaggerated pronunciation for younger ages

culturalConsiderations.representation: Include diverse names, family structures, cultural references
culturalConsiderations.languages: Incorporate simple words from multiple languages
culturalConsiderations.celebrations: Reference various cultural celebrations and traditions

specialNeeds.note: All songs should be accessible and adaptable for children with different abilities
considerations: Clear, predictable structures for autistic children
Multi-sensory elements for various learning styles
Movement adaptations for different motor abilities
